issues.description: The problem statement and UML require a no-argument method messageOnRide(): String (and the template Main invokes messageOnRide() with no arguments), but the solution repository defines Rideable.messageOnRide(int speed) and the implementations in Pig and Seal implement messageOnRide(int speed). This parameter mismatch means student code written to the specification (no-arg messageOnRide) will not match the solution's interface/implementations and the template Main's example call will not compile against the solution. It creates confusion about the intended method signature and prevents straightforward compilation or comparison between template, student implementation, and provided solution.
issues.suggested_fix: Make the Rideable API consistent across artifacts. Preferred fix: change the solution to match the problem/template by defining Rideable.messageOnRide() with no parameters (String messageOnRide()) and update Pig and Seal to implement the no-arg method, returning the string as specified in the problem (e.g., "Riding on Pig Doodle"). Alternatively, if the intent was to include a speed parameter, update the problem statement, UML, and template Main to document and use messageOnRide(int speed) (including updating the example calls and expected return string) so all artifacts match.

issues.description: The problem statement and template expect a no-argument ride method messageOnRide() that returns "Riding on [Animal Type] [name]" (see UML and example usage in Main). The solution, however, defines Rideable.messageOnRide(int speed) and implements messageOnRide(int speed) in Pig and Seal, returning strings that include speed (e.g. "Riding on Pig <name> at <speed> mph"). This is a signature and behavioral mismatch for the same conceptual operation (ride an animal). Students following the problem/template will try to call messageOnRide() with no arguments (the template's Main does so) and will find the solution's API incompatible, causing compile errors or test failures and creating unnecessary cognitive load mapping the requirement to the implementation.
issues.suggested_fix:
Make the ride API consistent across all artifacts. Either:
1) Align solution to the problem/template: change Rideable.messageOnRide(int speed) to messageOnRide() and update Pig and Seal to implement messageOnRide() returning exactly "Riding on [Animal Type] [name]" (no speed). This preserves the problem text, the UML, and the template Main usage. OR
2) If the speed parameter is intentional, update the problem statement UML, textual description, and template Main to declare and call messageOnRide(int speed) and update the expected return string to include speed. Prefer option (1) for minimal disruption and to match the provided problem requirements.
